SP.SPEAKER: L. Trink.
SP.P: How?—I was amazed You chose to see Her.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: How can You be so slow of Apprehen∣sion?—She comes You may be sure on some Occasion relating to this Girl: In order to assist young Oakly perhaps, to sooth me, and gain In∣telligence, and so forward the Match; but I'll forbid the Banns, I warrant You.—Whatever She wants, I'll draw some sweet Mischief out of it.—But away! away!—I think I hear her—slip down the back Stairs—or stay, now I think on't, go out this way,—meet Her,—and be sure to make Her a very respectful Bow, as You go out.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Trink.
SP.P: Hush! Here She is.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: I beg Pardon for giving your La∣dyship this Trouble.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: I am always glad of the Honour of seeing Mrs. Oakly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: There is a Letter, Madam, just come from the Country, which has occasioned some Alarm in our Family. It comes from Mr. Russet.—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: Mr. Russet!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Yes, from Mr. Russet, Madam! And is chiefly concerning his Daughter. As She has the Honour of being related to your Ladyship, I took the Liberty of waiting on You.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: She is indeed, as You say, Madam, a Relation of Mine; but after what has happened, I scarce know how to acknowledge Her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Has She been so much to blame then?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P:
So much? Madam!—Only judge for Yourself.—Though She had been so indiscreet,
not to say indecent in her Conduct, as to elope from her Father, I was in Hopes to have hushed up that Matter, for the Honour of our Family.—But She has run away from Me too, Madam!—Went off in the most abrupt Manner, not an Hour ago.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: You surprise Me. Indeed her Father, by his Letter, seems apprehensive of the worst Consequences.—But does your Ladyship imagine any Harm has happened?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: I can't tell—I hope not—But in∣deed She is a strange Girl. You know, Madam, young Women can't be too cautious in their Con∣duct. She is, I am sorry to declare it, a very dangerous Person to take into a Family.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Indeed! [Alarmed.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: If I was to say all I know!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Why sure your Ladyship knows of nothing that has been carried on clandestinely, between Her and Mr. Oakly. [In Disorder.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: Mr. Oakly!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Mr. Oakly—no, not Mr. Oakly—that is, not my Husband—I don't mean Him—not Him—but his Nephew—young Mr. Oakly.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: Jealous of her Husband!—So! so! Now I know my Game. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: But pray, Madam, give Me Leave to ask, was there any Thing very particular in her Conduct, while She was in your Ladyship's House?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: Why really, considering She was here scarce a Week, her Behaviour was rather mysteri∣ous; Letters and Messages, to and fro, between Her and I don't know who—I suppose You know that Mr. Oakly's Nephew has ##been here, Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: I was not sure of it. Has he been to wait on your Ladyship already on this Occasion?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: To wait on Me!—The Expression is much too polite for the Nature of his Visit.—My Lord Trinket, the Nobleman whom You met as You came in, had, You must know, Madam, some Thoughts of my Niece, and as it wou'd have been an advantageous Match, I was glad of it; but I believe, after what He has been Witness to this Morning, he will drop all Thoughts of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: I am sorry that any Relation of Mine shou'd so far forget Himself—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: It's no Matter—his Behaviour indeed, as well as the young Lady's, was pretty extraordi∣nary—And yet after all, I don't believe He is the Object of her Affections.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Ha! [Much alarmed.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: She has certainly an Attachment some∣where, a strong One; but his Lordship, who was present all the Time, was convinced, as well as Myself, that Mr. Oakly's Nephew was rather a convenient Friend, a kind of Go-between, than the Lover.—Bless Me, Madam, You change Colour! You seem uneasy: What's the Matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Nothing,—Madam,—Nothing—A little shocked that my Husband shou'd behave so.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: Your Husband! Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: His Nephew, I mean.—His un∣pardonable Rudeness—But I am not well—I am sorry I have given your Ladyship so much Trouble—I'll take my Leave.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P:
I declare, Madam, You frighten Me. Your being so visibly affected, makes Me quite uneasy: I hope I have not said any Thing—I really don't believe your Husband is in Fault.
Men, to be sure, allow themselves strange Liber∣ties. But I think, nay I am sure, it cannot be so. It is impossible. Don't let what I have said, have any Effect on You!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: No, it has not—I have no Idea of such a Thing—Your Ladyship's most obe∣dient—[Going, Returns.]—But sure, Madam, You have not heard, or don't know any Thing.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: Come, come, Mrs. Oakly, I see how it is, and it wou'd not be kind to say all I know. I dare not tell You what I have heard. Only, be on your Guard! There can be no Harm in that. Do You be against giving the Girl any Coun∣tenance, and see what Effect it has.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: I will—I am much obliged—But does it appear to your Ladyship then that Mr. Oakly—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: No, not at all—Nothing in't, I dare say.—I wou'd not create Uneasiness in a Family—But I am a Woman Myself, have been mar∣ried, and can't help feeling for You.—But don't be uneasy, there's nothing in't, I dare say.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: I think so.—Your Ladyship's humble Servant!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: Your Servant, Madam!—Pray, don't be alarmed, I must insist on your not making Yourself uneasy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Not at all alarmed—not in the least uneasy—Your most obedient! [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! There She goes, brim∣full of Anger and Jealousy, to vent it all on her Husband. Mercy on the poor Man!

DIV2.P: Bless Me! my Lord, I thought You was gone.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Trink.
SP.P: Only into the next Room. My Cu∣riosity wou'd not let me stir a Step further. I heard it all, and was never more diverted in my Life, 'pon Honour. Ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: How the silly Creature took it! Ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Trink.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha!—My dear Lady Freelove, You have a deal of Ingenuity, a deal of Esprit, 'pon Honour.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: A little Shell thrown into the Enemy's Works, that's all.

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: But I must leave You. I have twenty Visits to pay. You'll let Me know how You suc∣ceed in your secret Expedition.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Trink.
SP.P: That You may depend on.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: Remember then that To-morrow Morning I expect to see You.—At present your Lordship will excuse me.—Who's there? [Cal∣ling to the Servants.] Send Epingle into my Dressing-Room. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Trink.
SP.P: So!—If 'O Cutter and his Myrmi∣dons are alert, I think I can't fail of Success, and then prenez garde, Mademoiselle Harriot!—This is one of the drollest Circumstances in Nature.—Here is my Lady Freelove, a Woman of Sense, a Woman that knows the World too, assisting Me in this Design. I never knew her Ladyship so much out. How, in the Name of Wonder, can She imagine, that a Man of Quality, or any Man else 'egad, wou'd marry a fine Girl, after—Not I, 'pon Honour. No—no—When I have had the Entamure, let who will take the rest of the Loaf. [Exit▪

DIV2.STAGE: SCENE changes to Mr. Oakly's.—Enter Harriot following a Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Not at home!—Are You sure that Mrs. Oakly is not at home, Sir?—

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: She is just gone out, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: I have something of Consequence—If You will give me Leave, Sir, I will wait till She returns.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: You wou'd not see her, if You did, Madam. She has given positive Orders not to be interrupted with any Company To-day.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Sure, Sir, if You was to let Her know that I had particular Business—

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: I shou'd not dare to trouble Her indeed, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: How unfortunate this is! What can I do?—Pray, Sir, can I see MR. Oakly then?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Yes, Madam: I'll acquaint my Master, if You please.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Pray do, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Will You favour Me with your Name, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Be pleased, Sir, to let Him know that a Lady desires to speak with Him.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: I shall, Madam. [Exit Servant.

DIV2.P:
I wish I cou'd have seen MRS. Oakly! What an unhappy Situation am I reduced to! What will the World say of Me? And yet what cou'd I do? Charles, I must own, has this very Day revived much of my Tenderness for Him; and yet I dread the Wildness of his Disposition. I must now, however, sollicit Mr. Oakly's Protection, and beg
Leave to remain for some Time in his House; a Circumstance (all Things considered) rather dis∣agreeable to a delicate Mind, and which nothing, but the absolute Necessity of it, cou'd excuse. Good Heavens! What a Multitude of Difficulties and Distresses am I thrown into, by my Father's obstinate Perseverance to force Me into a Marriage, which my Soul abhors!

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: [At Entering.] Where is this Lady?—[Seeing Her.] Bless Me, Miss Russet, is it You?—Was ever any Thing so unlucky? [Aside.] Is it possible, Madam, that I see You here?

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: It is too true, Sir! And the Occasion on which I am now to trouble You, is so much in Need of an Apology, that—

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: Pray make none, Madam!—If my Wife shou'd return before I get Her out of the House again!—[Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: I dare say, Sir, You are not quite a Stranger to the Attachment your Nephew has profest to Me.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: I am not, Madam! I hope Charles has not been guilty of any Baseness toward You. If He has, I'll never see his Face again.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: I have no Cause to accuse Him. But—

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: But what? Madam! Pray be quick!—The very Person in the World I wou'd not have seen! [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: You seem uneasy, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: No, nothing at all—Pray, go on, Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: I am at present, Sir, through a Concur∣rence of strange Accidents, in a very unfortunate Situation, and do not know what will become of Me, without your Assistance.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: I'll do every thing in my Power to serve You. I know of your leaving your Father, by a Letter We have had from Him. Pray let me know the rest of your Story.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: My Story, Sir, is very short. When I left my Father's, I came immediately to London, and took Refuge with a Relation, where, instead of meeting with the Protection I expected, I was alarmed with the most infamous Designs upon my Honour. It is not an Hour ago, since your Ne∣phew rescued Me from the Attempts of a Villain. I tremble to think, that I left Him actually engaged in a Duel.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: He is very safe. He has just sent home the Chariot from the St. Alban's Tavern, where He dines To-Day. But what are your Commands for Me, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: I am heartily glad to hear of his Safety.—The Favour, Sir, I would now request of You is, that You will suffer Me to remain for a few Days in your House.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: And that in the mean Time You will use your utmost Endeavours to reconcile Me to my Father, without his forcing Me into a Marriage with Sir Harry Beagle.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: This is the most perplexing Situation!—Why did not Charles take Care to bestow You pro∣perly?

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: It is most probable, Sir, that I shou'd not have consented to such a Measure Myself. The World is but too apt to censure, even without a Cause: And if You are so kind as to admit Me into your House, I must desire not to consider Mr. Oakly in any other Light than as your Nephew, as in my present Circumstances I have particular Ob∣jections to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: What an unlucky Circumstance!—Upon my Soul, Madam, I wou'd do any Thing to serve You—But being in my House, creates a Difficulty that—

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: I hope, Sir, You do not doubt the Truth of what I have told You.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: I religiously believe every Tittle of it, Madam, but I have particular Family Considerations, that—

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Sure Sir, You cannot suspect Me to be base enough to form any Connections in your Family, contrary to your Inclinations, while I am living in your House.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: Such Connections, Madam, would do Me and all my Family great Honour. I never dreamt of any Scruples on that Account.—What can I do?—Let Me see—let Me see—suppose—[Pausing.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Mrs. Oakly behind, in a Capuchin, Tippet, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: I am sure I heard the Voice of a Woman conversing with my Husband.—Ha! [Seeing Harriot] It is so, indeed! Let Me con∣tain Myself—I'll listen.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: I see, Sir, You are not inclined to serve Me—Good Heaven! What am I reserved to?—Why? Why did I leave my Father's House to ex∣pose Myself to greater Distresses? [Ready to weep.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: I wou'd do any Thing for your sake: Indeed I would. So pray be comforted, and I'll think of some proper Place to bestow You in.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: So! So!

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: What Place can be so proper as your own House?

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: My dear Madam, I—I—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: My dear Madam—Mighty well!

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P:
Hush!—hark!—what Noise—No—nothing. But I'll be plain with You, Madam,
We may be interrupted.—The Family Considera∣tion I hinted at, is nothing else than my Wife. She is a little unhappy in her Temper, Madam!—And if You was to be admitted into the House, I don't know what might be the Consequence.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Very fine!—

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: My Behaviour, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: My dear Life, it wou'd be impossible for You to behave in such a Manner, as not to give Her Suspicion.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: But if your Nephew, Sir, took every Thing upon himself—

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: Still that wou'd not do, Madam!—Why this very Morning, when the Letter came from your Father, though I positively denied any Know∣ledge of it, and Charles owned it, yet it was almost impossible to pacify her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: The Letter!—How have I been bubbled!

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: What shall I do? What will become of Me?

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: Why, look'ye, my dear Madam, since my Wife is so strong an Objection, it is absolutely impossible for Me to take You into the House. Nay if I had not known She was gone out, just before You came, I shou'd be uneasy at your being here even now. So We must manage as well as We can. I'll take a private Lodging for You a little way off, unknown to Charles, or my Wife, or any Body; and if Mrs. Oakly shou'd discover it at last, why the whole Matter will light upon Charles, You know.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Upon Charles!

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: How unhappy is my Situation! [Weeping.] I am ruined for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P:
Ruined! Not at all. Such a Thing as this has happened to many a young Lady before You, and all has been well again.—Keep up your
Spirits! I'll contrive, if I possibly can, to visit You every Day.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: [Advancing.] Will You so? O Mr. Oakly! Have I discovered You at last? I'll visit You indeed. And You, my dear Madam, I'll—

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Madam, I don't understand—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: I understand the whole Affair, and have understood it for some Time past.—You shall have a private Lodging, Miss!—It is the fittest Place for You, I believe.—How dare You look Me in the Face?

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: For Heaven's Sake, my Love, don't be so violent.—You are quite wrong in this Affair—You don't know who You are talking to. That Lady is a Person of Fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Fine Fashion, indeed! To seduce other Women's Husbands!

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Dear Madam; how can You imagine—

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: I tell You, my Dear, this is the young Lady that Charles—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Mighty well! But that won't do, Sir!—Did not I hear You lay the whole Intrigue together? Did not I hear your fine Plot of throwing all the Blame upon Charles?—

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: Nay, be cool a Moment.—You must know, my Dear, that the Letter which came this Morning, related to this Lady—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: I know it.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: And since that, it seems, Charles has been so fortunate as to—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: O you deceitful Man!—That Trick is too stale to pass again with Me.—It is plain now what You meant by your proposing to take Her into the House this Morning.—But the Gen∣tlewoman cou'd introduce herself, I see.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: Fie! fie, my Dear, She came on purpose to enquire for You.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: For Me!—Better and better!—Did not She watch her Opportunity, and come to You just as I went out? But I am obliged to You for your Visit, Madam. It is sufficiently paid. Pray, don't let Me detain You.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: For Shame! For Shame, Mrs. Oakly! How can You be so absurd? Is this proper Beha∣viour to a Lady of her Character.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: I have heard her Character. Go, my fine run-away Madam! Now You've eloped from your Father, and run away from your Aunt! Go!—You shan't stay here, I promise You.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: Prithee, be quiet. You don't know what You are doing. She shall stay.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: She shan't stay a Minute.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: She shall stay a Minute, an Hour, a Day, a Week, a Month, a Year!—'Sdeath, Madam, She shall stay for ever, if I chuse it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: How!

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: For Heaven's Sake, Sir, let me go. I am frighted to Death.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: Don't be afraid, Madam!—She shall stay, I insist upon it.

SP.SPEAKER: Russet,
SP.P: within. I tell You, Sir, I will go up. I am sure that the Lady is here, and nothing shall hinder me.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: O my Father! My Father! [Faints away.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: See! She faints.—Ring the Bell! Who's there?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: What! Take Her into your Arms too!—Oh! I have no Patience.

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: Where is This—Ha! Fainting! [Run∣ning to Her.] O my dear Harriot! My Child! My Child!

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: Your coming so abruptly, shocked her Spirits. But She revives. How do You? Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: [To Rus.] O, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: O my dear Girl! How cou'd You run away from your Father, that loves You with such Fondness?—But I was sure I shou'd find You here?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: There!—There!—Sure he shou'd find Her here! Did not I tell You so?—Are not You a wicked Man, to carry on such base under∣hand Doings, with a Gentleman's Daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: Let Me tell You, Sir, whatever You may think of this Matter, I shall not easily put up with this Behaviour.—How durst You encourage my Daughter to an Elopement, and receive Her in your House?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: There, mind that!—The Thing is as plain as the Light.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: I tell You, You misunderstand—

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: Look ye, Mr. Oakly, I shall expect Satis∣faction from your Family for so gross an Affront. Zouns, Sir, I am not to be us'd ill by any Man in England.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: My dear Sir, I can assure you—

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: Hold your Tongue, Girl! you'll put me in a Passion.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: Sir, this is all a Mistake.

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: A Mistake! Did not I find her in your House?

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: Upon my Soul, she has not been in the House above—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Did not I hear You say, You wou'd take Her a Lodging? A private Lodging!

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: Yes, but that—

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: Has not this Affair been carried on a long Time in spite of my Teeth?

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: Sir, I never troubled Myself—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Never troubled Yourself!—Did not You insist on Her staying in the House, whether I wou'd or no?

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: Did not You send to meet Her when She came to Town?

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Did not You deceive Me about the Letter this Morning?

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: No—no—no—I tell You, No.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Yes—yes—yes—I tell You, Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: Shan't I believe my own Eyes?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Shant I believe my own Ears?

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: I tell You, You are both deceiv'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: Zouns, Sir, I'll have Satisfaction.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: I'll stop these fine Doings, I warrant You.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: 'Sdeath, You will not let me speak—And You are both alike, I think—I wish You were married to one another with all my Heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Mighty well! Mighty well!

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: I shall soon find a Time to talk with You.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: Find a Time to talk! You have talked enough now for all your Lives.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Very fine! Come along, Sir! Leave that Lady with her Father. Now She is in the properest Hands. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: I wish I cou'd leave You in his Hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: [Going, Returns.] I shall follow You, Ma∣dam!—One Word with You, Sir!—The Height of your Passion, and Mrs. Oakly's strange Misapprehension of this whole Affair, makes it impossible to explain Matters to You at present. I will do it when You please, and how You please. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: Yes, yes: I'll have Satisfaction.—So, Madam! I have found You at last.—You have made a fine Confusion here.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: I have indeed been the innocent Cause of a great deal of Confusion.

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: Innocent!—What Business had You to be running hither after—

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: My dear Sir, You misunderstand the whole Affair. I have not been in this House half an Hour.

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: Zouns, Girl, don't put Me in a Passion!—You know I love You—but a Lie puts Me in a Passion. But come along—We'll leave this House directly—[Charles singing without.] Hey∣day! what now?

DIV2.STAGE: After a Noise without, Enter Charles, drunk.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.L: But my Wine neither Nurses nor Babies can bring,
And a big-bellied Bottle's a mighty good Thing.
SP.P: What's here? a Woman? Harriot! Impossible! My dearest, sweetest Harriot! I have been looking all over the Town for You, and at last—when I was tired—and weary—and disappointed—why then the honest Major and I sat down together to drink your Health in pint Bumpers. [Running up to Her.

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: Stand off!—How dare You take any Li∣berties with my Daughter before Me? Zouns, Sir, I'll be the Death of You.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P:
Ha! 'Squire Russet too!—You jolly old Cock, how do You?—But Harriot! My
dear Girl! [Taking hold of Her.] My Life, my Soul, my—

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: Let Her go, Sir—Come away, Harriot!—Leave Him this Instant, or I'll tear You asunder. [Pulling Her.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: There needs no Violence to tear Me from a Man, who cou'd disguise himself in such a gross Manner, at a Time when He knew I was in the utmost Distress. [Disengages Herself, and Exit with Russet.

DIV2.P: Only hear Me, Sir!—Madam!—My dear Harriot—Mr. Russet!—Gone!—She's gone!—and 'egad in very ill Humour, and in very bad Company!—I'll go after Her—But hold!—I shall only make it worse—as I did—now I recollect—once before. How the Devil came They here?—Who wou'd have thought of finding Her in my own House?—My Head turns round with Conjectures.—I believe I am drunk,—very drunk—so 'egad, I'll e'en go and sleep myself sober, and then enquire the Mean∣ing of all this. For, I love Sue, and Sue loves Me, &c. [Exit. singing.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT IV.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter Mrs. Oakly, and Major Oakly.

SP.SPEAKER: Major.
SP.P: WELL—well—But Sister!—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: I will know the Truth of this Matter. Why can't You tell me the whole Story?

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: I'll tell you nothing.—There's nothing to tell.—You know the Truth already.—Besides, what have I to do with it? Suppose there was a Disturbance Yesterday,—What's that to Me? Was I here? It's no Business of mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Then why do You study to make it so? Am I not well assur'd that this Mischief com∣menced at your House in the Country? And now you are carrying it on in Town.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: This is always the Case in Family-Squab∣bles. My Brother has put You out of Humour, and You chuse to vent your Spleen upon Me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Because I know that You are the Oc∣casion of his Ill-usage. Mr. Oakly never behaved in such a Manner before.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: I! Am I the Occasion of it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Yes, You. I am sure on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: I am glad on't with all my Heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Ay, indeed: And You are the more oblig'd to me.—Come, come, Sister, its Time You shou'd reflect a little. My Brother is become a publick Jest; and by-and-by, if this foolish Affair gets Wind, the whole Family will be the Subject of Town∣talk.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: And well it may, when You take so much Pains to expose us.—The little Disquiets and Uneasinesses of other Families are kept secret; but here Quarrels are fomented, and afterwards in∣dustriously made publick—And You, Sir, You have done all this—You are my greatest Enemy.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Your truest Friend, Sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: But its no Wonder. You have no Feelings of Humanity, no Sense of Domestick Happiness, no Idea of Tenderness or Attachment to any Woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: No Idea of Plague or Disquiet—No, no—And yet I can love a Woman for all that—heartily—As you say, tenderly—But then I al∣ways chuse a Woman shou'd shew a little Love for me too.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Cruel Insinuation!—But I defy your Malice—Mr. Oakly can have no Doubt of my Affection for Him.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Nor I neither; and yet your Affection, such as it is, has all the evil Properties of Aversion. You absolutely kill Him with Kindness. Why, what a Life He leads! He serves for nothing but a mere Whetstone of your Ill-humour.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Pray now, Sir!—

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: The Violence of your Temper makes his House uncomfortable to Him, poisons his Meals, and breaks his Rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: I beg, Major Oakly, that—

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: This it is to have a Wife that doats upon one!—The least Trifle kindles your Suspicion; You take Fire in an Instant, and set the whole Fa∣mily in a Blaze.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: This is beyond all Patience—No, Sir, 'tis You are the Incendiary. You are the Cause of—I can't bear such—[Ready to weep.]—From this Instant, Sir, I forbid You my House. However Mr. Oakly may treat Me himself, I'll never be made the Sport of all his insolent Rela∣tions. [Exit.

DIV2.P: Yes, yes, I knew I shou'd be turn'd out of Doors. There she goes—Back again to my Brother di∣rectly. Poor Gentleman!—'Slife, if He was but half the Man that I am, I'd engage to keep Her going to and fro all Day, like a Shuttlecock.
What, Charles!

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: O Major! Have You heard of what hap∣pened after I left you Yesterday?

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Heard! Yes, yes, I have heard it plain enough. But poor Charles! Ha! ha! ha! What a Scene of Confusion! I wou'd give the World to have been there.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: And I wou'd give the World to have been any where else. Cursed Fortune!

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: To come in so opportunely at the Tail of an Adventure!—Was not your Mistress mighty glad to see You? You was very fond of Her, I dare say.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P:
I am upon the Rack. Who can tell what Rudeness I might offer Her? I can remember
nothing—I deserve to lose Her—To make My∣self a Beast!—And at such a Time too!—O Fool! Fool! Fool!

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Prithee be quiet, Charles!—Never vex Yourself about nothing, this will all be made up the first Time You see Her.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: I shou'd dread to see Her—And yet the not knowing where she is, distracts me—Her Fa∣ther may force Her to marry Sir Harry Beagle im∣mediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Not He, I promise You. She'd run plum into your Arms first, in spite of her Father's Teeth.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: But then Her Father's Violence, and the Mildness of her Disposition—

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Mildness!—Ridiculous!—Trust to the Spirit of the Sex in Her. I warrant You, like all the rest, she'll have Perverseness enough not to do as her Father would have Her.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: Well—well—But then my Behaviour to her—To expose Myself in such a Condition to Her again! The very Occasion of our former Quarrel!—

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Quarrel! ha! ha! ha! What signifies a Quarrel with a Mistress? Why, the whole Affair of making Love, as they call it, is nothing but quarrelling and making it up again. They quarrel o' purpose to kiss and be Friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: Then indeed Things seemed to be taking a fortunate Turn—To renew our Difference at such a Time!—Just when I had some Reason to hope for a Reconciliation!—May Wine be my Poison if ever I am drunk again!

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Ay, ay, so every Man says the next Morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P:
Where! where can she be? Her Father wou'd hardly have carried Her back to Lady
Freelove's, and He has no House in Town Himself, nor Sir Harry—I don't know what to think—I'll go in search of Her, though I dont know where to direct Myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: A Gentleman, Sir, that calls Himself Captain 'O Cutter desires to speak with You.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: Don't trouble Me—I'll see nobody—I'm not at home—

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: The Gentleman says He has very particu∣lar Business, and he must see You.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: What's his Name? Who did You say?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Captain 'O Cutter, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: Captain 'O Cutter! I never heard of Him before. Do You know any Thing of Him, Ma∣jor?

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Not I—But You hear He has particular Business. I'll leave the Room.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: He can have no Business that need be a Se∣cret to You—Desire the Captain to walk up. [Exit Servant.] What wou'd I give if this unknown Captain was to prove a Messenger from my Har∣riot!

SP.SPEAKER: 'O Cut.
SP.P: Jontlemen, your Servant! Is either of your Names Charles Oakly, Esq.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: Charles Oakly, Sir, is my Name, if You have any Business with it.

SP.SPEAKER: 'O Cut.
SP.P: Avast, avast, my Dear!—I have a little Business with your Name, but as I was to let nobody know it, I can't mention it, till You clear the Decks, fait. [Pointing to the Major.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: This Gentleman, Sir, is my most intimate Friend, and any Thing that concerns Me may be mentioned before Him.

SP.SPEAKER: 'O Cut.
SP.P: O, if he's your Friend, my Dear, we may do all above-board. Its only about your de∣ciding a Deferance with my Lord Trinket. He wants to shew You a little warm Work; and as I was steering this Way, He desir'd Me to bring you this Letter. [Giving a Letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: How, Sir, a Challenge!

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: [Reading.] Ha! What's this? This may be useful. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: 'O Cut.
SP.P: Yes, fait, a Challenge. I am to be his Lordship's Second; and if You are fond of a hot Birth, and will come along with that Jontleman, we'll all go to it together, and make a little Line of Battle a-head of our own, my Dear!

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Sir, I am infinitely oblig'd to You—A rare Fellow this! [Aside. Yes, yes, I'll meet all the good Company. I'll be there in my Waistcoat and Pumps, and take a Morning's Breathing with You. Are You very fond of Fighting? Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: 'O Cut.
SP.P: Indeed and I am. I love it better than Salt Beef or Biscuit.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: But pray, Sir, how are You interested in this Difference? Do You know what it is about?

SP.SPEAKER: 'O Cut.
SP.P: O the Devil burn Me, not I. What sig∣nifies what it's about, You know? so we do but tilt a little.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: What! fight and not know for what?

SP.SPEAKER: 'O Cut.
SP.P: When the Signal's out for Engaging, What signifies talking?

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: I fancy, Sir, a Duel is a common Breakfast with You. I'll warrant now, You have been en∣gag'd in many such Affairs.

SP.SPEAKER: 'O Cut.
SP.P:
Upon my Shoul, and I have; Sea or Land, its all one to little Terence 'O Cutter—When I was last in Dublin, I fought one Jontleman for cheating me out of a tousand Pounds: I fought two of the Mermaid's Crew about Sally Mac guire;
tree about Politicks; and one about the Play-house in Smock-Alley. But upon my fait! since I am in England, I have done noting at all, at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: This is lucky—but my Transport will dis∣cover Me. [Aside.] Will You be so kind, Sir, [To 'O Cutter.] as to make my Compliments to his Lordship, and assure Him that I shall do Myself the Honour of waiting on Him.

SP.SPEAKER: 'O Cut.
SP.P: Indeed, and I will.—Arrah, my Dear, wont You come too? [To Maj. Oakly.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Depend upon't. We'll go thro' the whole Exercise: Carte, Tierce, and Segoon, Captain!

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: Now to get my Intelligence. [Aside.] I think the Time, Sir, his Lordship appoints, in his Letter, is—a—

SP.SPEAKER: 'O Cut.
SP.P: You say right—Six o'Clock.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: And the Place—a—a—is—I think, be∣hind Montague House.

SP.SPEAKER: 'O Cut.
SP.P: No, my Dear!—Avast, by the Ring in Hyde-Park, fait.—I settled it there Myself for fare of Interruption.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: True, as You say, the Ring in Hyde-Park—I had forgot—Very well, I'll not fail You, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: 'O Cut.
SP.P: Devil burn Me, nor I. Upon my Shoul little Terence 'O Cutter will see fair Play, or he'll know the Reason—And so, my Dear, your Ser∣vant. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! What a Fellow!—He loves Fighting, like a Game-cock.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: O Uncle! the luckiest Thing in the World!

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: What, to have a Chance of being run through the Body! I desire no such good For∣tune.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: Wish Me Joy, wish Me Joy! I have found Her, my dear Girl, my Harriot!—She is at an Inn in Holborn, Major!

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: The Devil she is! How do You know!

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: Why this dear, delightful, charming, blun∣dering Captain, has delivered me a wrong Letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: A wrong Letter!

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: Yes, a Letter to Lady Freelove.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: The Devil! What are the Contents?

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: The News I told You just now, that She's at an Inn in Holborn:—And besides, an Excuse from my Lord, for not waiting on her Ladyship this Morning, according to his Promise, as He shall be entirely taken up with his Design upon Harriot.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: So!—so!—A Plot between the Lord and the Lady!—

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: What his Plot is I don't know, but I shall beg Leave to be made a Party in it: So perhaps his Lordship and I may meet, and decide our De∣ferance, as the Captain calls it, before To-morrow Morning.—There! read, read, Man!

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: [Reading.] Um—um—um—Very fine! And what do You propose doing?

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: To go thither immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Then You shall take Me with You. Who knows what his Lordship's Designs may be? I be∣gin to suspect foul Play.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: No, no; pray mind your own Business. If I find there is any need of your Assistance, I'll send for You.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: You'll manage this Affair like a Boy now—Go on rashly with Noise and Bustle, and Fury, and get Yourself into another Scrape.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P:
No—no—Let Me alone; I'll go incog.—Leave my Chariot at some Distance—Proceed pru∣dently, and take care of Myself, I warrant You—
I did not imagine that I shou'd ever rejoice at re∣ceiving a Challenge, but this is the most fortu∣nate Accident that cou'd possibly have happen'd. B'ye, b'ye, Uncle! [Exit hastily.

DIV2.P: I don't half approve this—and yet I can hardly suspect his Lordship of any very deep Designs neither.—Charles may easily outwit im. Hark ye, William! [as seeing a Servant at some Distance.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Where's my Brother?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: In his Study—alone, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: And how is He? William!

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Pretty well, I believe, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Ay, ay, but is He in good Humour, or a little—

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: I never meddle in family Affairs, not I, Sir! [Exit.

DIV2.P:
Well said, William!—No bad Hint for Me, perhaps!—What a strange World We live in!—No two People in it love one another better than my Brother and Sister, and yet the bitterest Enemies cou'd not torment each other more heartily—Ah, if He had but half my Spirit!—And yet he don't want it neither—But I know his Temper—He pieces out the Matter with Maxims, and Scraps of Philosophy, and Odds and Ends of Sentences—I must live in Peace—Patience is the best Remedy—Any thing for a quiet Life! and so on—However, Yesterday, to give Him his Due, he behaved like a Man. Keep it up, Brother! Keep it up! Or it's all over with You.
Since Mischief is on Foot, I'll e'en set it forwardś on all Sides. I'll in to Him directly, read Him one of my Morning Lectures, and persuade Him, if I possibly can, to go out with Me immediately, or work Him up to some open Act of Rebellion against the sovereign Authority of his Lady-Wife. Zouns, Brother, rant, and roar, and rave, and turn the House out of Window. If I was a Husband!—'Sdeath, what a Pity it is, that No∣body knows how to manage a Wife, but a Batchelor!
DIV2.STAGE: SCENE changes to the Bull and Gate Inn.
DIV2.P: What will become of Me? My Father is en∣raged, and deaf to all Remonstrances, and here I am to remain by his positive Orders, to receive this booby Baronet's odious Addresses.—Among all my Distresses, I must confess that Charles his Be∣haviour Yesterday is not the least. So wild! So given up to Excesses! And yet—I am ashamed to own it even to Myself—I love Him: And Death itself shall not prevail on Me to give my Hand to Sir Harry.—But here He comes! What shall I do with Him?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Har.
SP.P:
Your Servant, Miss!—What! Not speak!—Bashful mayhap—Why then I will.—Look'ye, Miss, I am a Man of few Words.—What signifies Hagling? It looks just like a Dealer.—What d'ye think of Me for an Husband?—I am a tight young Fellow—sound wind and
Limb—free from all natural Blemishes—Rum all over, dammee.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Sir, I don't understand You. Speak English, and I'll give You an Answer.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Har.
SP.P: English! Why so I do—and good plain English too.—What d'ye think of Me for an Husband?—That's English—e'nt it?—I know none of your French Lingo, none of your Parlyvoos, not I.—What d'ye think of Me for an Husband? The 'Squire says You shall marry Me.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: What shall I say to Him? I had best be civil. [Aside.]—I think, Sir, You deserve a much better Wife, and beg—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Har.
SP.P: Better! No, no—though You're so knowing, I am not to be taken in so.—You're a fine Thing—Your Points are all good.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Sir Harry! Sincerity is above all Cere∣mony. Excuse Me, if I declare I never will be your Wife. And if You have a real Regard for Me and my Happiness, You will give up all Pre∣tension to Me. Shall I beseech You, Sir, to per∣suade my Father not to urge a Marriage, to which I am determined never to consent?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Har.
SP.P: Hey! how! what! be off!—Why it's a Match, Miss!—It's done and done on both Sides.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: For Heaven's Sake, Sir, withdraw your Claim to Me.—I never can be prevailed on—indeed I can't—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Har.
SP.P: What! make a Match, and then draw the Stakes! That's doing of nothing—play or pay, all the World over.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Let Me prevail on You, Sir!—I am de∣termined not to marry You at all Events.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Har.
SP.P:
But your Father's determined You shall, Miss!—So the Odds are on my Side.—
I am not quite sure of my Horse, but I have the Rider hollow.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Your Horse! Sir—D'ye take Me for—but I forgive You.—I beseech You, come into my Proposal. It will be better for us both in the End.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Har.
SP.P: I can't be off.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Let Me intreat You.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Har.
SP.P: I tell You, its unpossible.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Pray, pray do, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Har.
SP.P: I can't, dammee.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: I beseech You.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: How! laugh'd at?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Har.
SP.P: Will You marry Me? Dear Ally, Ally Croker! [singing.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Marry You? I had rather be married to a Slave, a Wretch—You! [Walks about.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Har.
SP.P: A fine going Thing,—She has a deal of Foot—treads well upon her Pasterns—goes above her Ground—

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Peace! Wretch—Do You talk to Me as if I were your Horse?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Har.
SP.P: Horse! Why not speak of my Horse? If your fine Ladies had half as many good Qua∣lities, they wou'd be much better Bargains.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: And if their Wretches of Husbands liked them half so well as they do their Horses. they wou'd lead better Lives.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Har.
SP.P: May-hap so.—But what signifies talking to You?—The 'Squire shall know your Tricks—He'll doctor You,—I'll go and talk to Him.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Go any where, so that You go from Me▪

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Har.
SP.P: He'll break You in—If You won't go in a Snaffle, You must be put in a Curb—He'll break You, dammee. [Exit.

DIV2.P: A Wretch!—But I was to blame to suffer his brutal Behaviour to ruffle my Temper.—I cou'd expect nothing else from Him, and He is below my Anger.—How much Trouble has this odious Fellow caused both to Me and my poor Father!—I never disobey'd him before, and my Denial now makes him quite unhappy. In any Thing else I wou'd be all Submission; and even now, while I dread his Rage, my Heart bleeds for his Uneasi∣ness—I wish I cou'd resolve to obey Him!

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: Are not You a sad Girl? a perverse, stub∣born, obstinate—

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: My dear Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: Look ye, Harriot, don't speak—You'll put me in a Passion—Will You have Him?—Answer me that—Why don't the Girl speak?—Will You have Him?

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Dearest Sir, there is nothing in the World else—

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: Why there!—there!—Look ye there!—Zouns, You shall have Him—Hussy, You shall have Him—You shall marry him To-night—Did not You promise to receive Him civilly?—How came You to affront Him?

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Sir, I did receive Him very civilly; but his Behaviour was so insolent and insupportable—

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P:
Insolent!—Zouns, I'll blow his Brains out.—Insolent to my dear Harriot!—A Rogue! a Villain! a Scoundrel! I'll—But its a Lie—I know its a Lie—He durst not behave insolent—
Will You have Him? Answer Me that. Will You have Him?—Zouns, You shall have Him.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: If You have any Love for Me, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: Love for You!—You know I love You—You know your poor fond Father doats on You to Madness—I wou'd not force You, if I did not love You—Don't I want You to be happy?—But I know what You wou'd have. You want young Oakly, a rakehelly, drunken—

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Release Me from Sir Harry, and if I ever marry against your Consent, renounce Me for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: I will renounce You, unless you'll have Sir Harry.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Consider, my dear Sir, you'll make Me miserable. I wou'd die to please You, but cannot prostitute my Hand to a Man, my Heart abhors.—Absolve Me from this hard Command, and in every Thing else it will be Happiness to obey You.

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: You'll break my Heart, Harriot, you'll break my Heart—Make You miserable!—Don't I want to make You happy? Is not He the richest Man in the County?—That will make You happy.—Don't all the pale-faced Girls in the Country long to get Him?—And yet You are so perverse, and wayward, and stubborn—Zouns You shall have Him.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: For Heaven's sake, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P:
Hold your Tongue, Harriot!—I'll hear none of your Nonsense.—You shall have Him, I tell You, You shall have Him—He shall marry You this very Night—I'll go for a Licence and a Parson immediately Zouns! Why do I stand arguing with You? An't I your Father? Have
not I a Right to dispose of You? You shall have Him.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Sir!—

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: I won't hear a Word. You shall have Him. [Exit.

DIV2.P: Sir!—Hear Me!—but one Word!—He will not hear Me, and is gone to prepare for this odious Marriage. I will die before I consent to it. You shall have him! O that Fathers wou'd enforce their Commands by better Arguments!—And yet I pity Him, while He afflicts Me.—He up∣braided Me with Charles his Wildness and Intem∣perance—Alas! but too justly—I see that He is wedded to his Excesses; and I ought to conquer an Affection for Him, which will only serve to make Me unhappy.
Ha! What do I see? [Screaming.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: Peace! my Love!—My dear Life, make no Noise!—I have been hovering about the House this Hour—I just now saw your Father and Sir Harry go out, and have seized this precious Opportunity to throw Myself at your Feet.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: You have given Yourself, Sir, a great deal of needless Trouble. I did not expect or hope for the Favour of such a Visit.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P:
O my dear Harriot, your Words and Looks cut Me to the Soul. You can't imagine what I suffer, and have suffer'd since last Night—And yet I have in some fond Moments flatter'd My∣self, that the Service I was so fortunate as to do You
at Lady Freelove's, wou'd plead a little in my Fa∣vour.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: You may remember, Sir, that You took a very early Opportunity of cancelling that Obli∣gation.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: I do remember it with Shame and Despair. But may I perish, if my Joy at having delivered You from a Villain, was not the Cause! My Trans∣port more than half intoxicated Me, and Wine made an easy Conquest over Me.—I tremble to think lest I shou'd have behav'd in such Manner, as You cannot pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Whether I pardon You or no, Sir, is a Matter of mighty little Consequence.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: O my Harriot! Upbraid Me, reproach Me, do any Thing but look and talk with that Air of Coldness and Indifference. Must I lose You for one Offence? when my Soul doats on You, when I love You to Distraction?

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Did it appear like Love, your Conduct Yesterday? To lose Yourself in Riot, when I was exposed to the greatest Distresses?

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: I feel, I feel my Shame, and own it.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: You confess that You don't know in what Manner You behaved. Ought not I to tremble at the very Thoughts of a Man, devoted to a Vice, which renders him no longer a Judge or Master of his own Conduct?

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P:
Abandon Me, if ever I am guilty of it again. O Harriot! I am distracted with ten thou∣sand Fears and Apprehensions of losing You for ever—The Chambermaid, whom I brib'd to admit Me to You, told Me that when the two Gentlemen went out, they talk'd of a Licence.—What am I to think? Is it possible that You can resign Your∣self to Sir Harry Beagle? [Harriot pauses.] Can You then consent to give your Hand to another?
No, let Me once more deliver You—Let us seize this lucky Moment!—My Chariot stands at the Corner of the next Street—Let Me gently force You, while their Absence allows it, and convey You from the brutal Violence of a constrained Marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: No!—I will wait the Event, be it what it may—O Charles, I am too much inclin'd—They shan't force Me to marry Sir Harry—But your Behaviour—Not half an Hour ago, my Father reproach'd Me with the Looseness of your Character. [Weeping.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: I see my Folly, and am asham'd of it. You have reclaim'd Me, Harriot!—On my Soul, You have.—If all Women were as attentive as Yourself to the Morals of their Lovers, a Liber∣tine wou'd be an uncommon Character.—But let Me persuade You to leave this Place, while You may—Major Oakly will receive us at his House with Pleasure—I am shock'd at the Thoughts of what your Stay here may reserve You to.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: No, I am determin'd to remain.—To leave my Father again, to go off openly with a Man, of whose libertine Character He has Him∣self so lately been a Witness, wou'd justify his An∣ger, and impeach my Reputation.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: Fool! Fool! How unhappy have I made Myself!—Consider, my Harriot, the Peculiarity of your Situation; besides, I have Reason to fear other Designs against You.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: From other Designs I can be no where so secure as with my Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: Time flies—Let Me persuade You!

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: I am resolved to stay here.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: You distract Me. For Heaven's sake—

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: I will not think of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: Consider, my Angel!—

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: I do consider, that your Conduct has made it absolutely improper for me to trust Myself to your Care.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: My Conduct!—Vexation! 'Sdeath!—But then, my dear Harriot, the Danger You are in, the Necessity—

SP.SPEAKER: Chamb.
SP.P: O Law, Ma'am!—Such a terrible Accident!—As sure as I am here, there's a Press-Gang has seized the two Gemmin, and is carrying them away, thof so be one an 'em says as how He's a Knight and Baronight, and that t'other's a 'Squire and a Housekeeper.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Seized by a Press-Gang! Impossible.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: O, now the Design comes out.—But I'll balk his Lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: Chamb.
SP.P: Lack-a-dasy, Ma'am, what can We do? There is Master, and John Ostler, and Boot-catcher, all gone a'ter 'em.—There is such an Uproar as never was. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: If I thought this was your Contrivance, Sir, I wou'd never speak to You again.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: I wou'd sooner die than be guilty of it. This is Lord Trinket's doing, I am sure. I knew He had some Scheme in Agitation, by a Letter I intercepted this Morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: Ha! Here He comes! Nay then, it's plain enough. Don't be frighted, my Love! I'll protect You.—But now I must desire You to follow my Directions.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Trink.
SP.P: Now, Madam!—Pox on't, He here again!—Nay then! [Drawing.] Come, Sir! You're unarmed, I see. Give up the Lady: Give Her up, I say, or I am through You in a Twink∣ling. [Going to make a Pass at Charles.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: Keep your Distance, my Lord! I have Arms. [Producing a Pistol.] If You come a Foot nearer, You have a Brace of Balls thro' your Lord∣ship's Head.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Trink.
SP.P: How? What's this? Pistols!

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: At your Lordship's Service.—Sword and Pistol, my Lord!—Those You know, are our Weapons.—If this misses, I have the Fellow to't in my Pocket.—Don't be frighted, Madam! His Lordship has removed your Friends and Re∣lations, but He will take great Care of You. Shall I leave You with Him?

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Cruel Charles! You know I must go with You now.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: A little away from the Door, if your Lordship pleases. [Waving his Hand.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Trink.
SP.P: Sir!—'Sdeath!—Madam!—

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: A little more round, my Lord! [Waving.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Trink.
SP.P: But Sir!—Mr. Oakly!—

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: I have no Leisure to talk with your Lord∣ship now.—A little more that Way, if You please. [Waving.]—You know where I live—If You have any Commands for Miss Russet, You will hear of Her too at my House.—Nay, keep back, my Lord! [Presenting.]—Your Lord∣ship's most obedient humble Servant!

DIV2.STAGE: [Looking after them, and pausing for a short Time.]
DIV2.P: —I cut a mighty ridiculous Figure here, 'pon Honour.—So I have been concerting this deep Scheme, merely to serve Him.—Oh, the Devil take such Intrigues, and all silly country Girls, that can give up a Man of Quality and Figure, for a Fellow that Nobody knows! [Exit.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT V.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter Lord Trinket, Lady Freelove with a Letter, and Captain 'O Cutter.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Trinket.
SP.P: WAS ever any Thing so unfortunate? Pox on't, Captain, how cou'd You make such a strange Blunder?

SP.SPEAKER: 'O Cut.
SP.P: I never tought of a Blunder. I was to daliver two Letters, and if I gave Them one a-piece I tought it was all one, fait.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: And so, my Lord, the ingenious Cap∣tain gave the Letter intended for Me to young Oakly, and here he has brought me a Challenge.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Trink.
SP.P: Ridiculous! Never was any Thing so mal-apropos—Did not You read the Direction? Captain!

SP.SPEAKER: 'O Cut.
SP.P: Who Me!—Devil burn Me, not I. I never rade at all.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Trink.
SP.P: 'Sdeath! How provoking! When I had secur'd the Servants, and got all the People out of the Way—When every Thing was en train.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: Nay, never despair, my Lord! Things have happened unluckily, to be sure; and yet I think I cou'd hit upon a Method to set every Thing to Right again.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Trink.
SP.P: How? how? My dear Lady Freelove, How?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: Suppose then your Lordship was to go and deliver these country Gentlemen from their Confinement; make them believe that it was a Plot of young Oakly's to carry off my Niece; and so make a Merit of your own Services with the Fa∣ther.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Trink.
SP.P: Admirable! I'll about it immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: 'O Cut.
SP.P: Has your Lordship any Occasion for my Sarvice in this Expedition?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Trink.
SP.P: O no: Only release Me these People, and then keep out of the Way, dear Captain!

SP.SPEAKER: 'O Cut.
SP.P: With all my Heart, fait! But You are all wrong! this will not signify a Brass Farding. If You wou'd let Me alone, I wou'd give Him a Salt Eel, I warrant You—But upon my Credit—There's nothing to be done without a little Tilting. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: Ha! ha! Poor Captain!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Trink.
SP.P: But where shall I carry them, when I have deliver'd them!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: To Mr. Oakly's, by all Means. You may be sure my Niece is there.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Trink.
SP.P: To Mr. Oakly's!—Why, does your Ladyship consider? 'Tis going directly into the Fire of the Enemy—throwing the Dementi full in their Teeth.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P:
So much the better. Face your Ene∣mies: Nay, You shall outface Them too. Why, where's the Difference between Truths and Un∣truths, if You do but stick close to the Point?
Falshood wou'd scarce ever be detected, if We had Confidence enough to support it?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Trink.
SP.P: Nay, I don't want Bronze upon Oc∣casion—But to go amongst a whole Troop of People, sure to contradict every Word I say, is so dangerous—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: To leave Russet alone amongst Them, wou'd be ten times more dangerous. You may be sure that Oakly's will be the first Place He will go to after his Daughter, where, if You don't accompany Him, He will be open to all their Suggestions. They'll be all in one Story, and No∣body there to contradict Them: And then their dull Truth wou'd triumph, which must not be. No—no—positively, my Lord, You must battle it out.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Trink.
SP.P: —Well! I'll go, 'pon Honour—and if I cou'd depend on your Ladyship as a Corps de reserve—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: I'll certainly meet You there.—Tush! my Lord, there's nothing in it. It's hard indeed if two Persons of Condition can't bear themselves out against such trumpery Folks as the Family of the Oaklys.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Trink.
SP.P: Odious low People!—But I lose Time—I must after the Captain—and so, till We meet at Mr. Oakly's, I kiss your Ladyship's Hands.—You won't fail Me.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: You may depend on Me. [Exit L. Trink.

DIV2.P:
So here is fine Work! This artful little Hussy has been too much for Us all: Well! what's to be done? Why, when a Woman of Fashion gets into a Scrape, nothing but a Fashionable Assurance can get Her out of it again. I'll e'en go boldly to
Mr. Oakly's, as I have promised, and if it appears practicable, I will forward Lord Trinket's Match; but if I find that Matters have taken another Turn, his Lordship must excuse Me. In that Case I'll fairly drop Him, seem a perfect Stranger to all his Intentions, and give my Visit an Air of Congra∣tulation to my Niece and any other Husband, which Fortune, her wise Father, or Her ridiculous Self, has provided for Her. [Exit.
DIV2.STAGE: SCENE changes to Mrs. Oakly's Dressing-Room.
DIV2.P: This is worse and worse!—He never held Me so much in Contempt before—To go out without so much as speaking to Me, or taking the least Notice!—I am obliged to the Major for this.—How cou'd He take Him out? And how cou'd Mr. Oakly go with Him?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Well, Toilet!

SP.SPEAKER: Toil.
SP.P: My Master is not come back yet; Ma'am!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Where is He gone?

SP.SPEAKER: Toil.
SP.P: I don't know, I can assure your Ladyship.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Why don't You know?—You know nothing—But I warrant You know well enough, if You wou'd tell—You shall never persuade Me but You knew of Mr. Oakly's going out To-day.

SP.SPEAKER: Toil.
SP.P: I wish I may die, Ma'am, upon my Honour, and I protest to your Ladyship, I knew nothing in the World of the Matter, no more than the Child unborn. There is Mr. Paris, my Master's Gen∣tleman, knows—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: What does He know?

SP.SPEAKER: Toil.
SP.P: That I knew nothing about it, till after my Master was gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Where is Paris? What is He doing?

SP.SPEAKER: Toil.
SP.P: He is in my Master's Room, Ma'am!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Bid Him come here.

SP.SPEAKER: Toil.
SP.P: Yes, Ma'am! [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: He is certainly gone after this young Flirt.—His Confidence and the Major's Insolence provokes Me beyond Expression.

DIV2.P: Where's your Master?

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: Il est sortie.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Where is He gone?

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: Ah, Madame! Je n'en sai rien. I know noting of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Nobody knows any Thing. Why did not You tell Me He was going out?

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: I dress Him—Je ne m'en soucie pas du plus—He go where He will—I have no Bisness wis it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Yes, You shou'd have told Me—That was your Business—And if You don't mind your Business better, You shan't stay here, I can tell You, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: Voila! quelque chose d'extraordinaire!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Don't stand jabbering and shrugging your Shoulders, but go, and enquire—go—and bring Me Word where He is gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: I don't know vat I am do—I'll ask John.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Bid John come here.

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: De tout mon coeur.—Jean! ici! Jean!—Speak mi Ladi! [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Impudent Fellow! His insolent Gra∣vity and Indifference is insupportable—Toilet!

SP.SPEAKER: Toil.
SP.P: Ma'am!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Where's John? Why don't He come? Why do You stand with your Hands before You? Why don't You fetch Him?

SP.SPEAKER: Toil.
SP.P: Yes, Ma'am—I'll go this Minute—O! here! John! My Lady wants You.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Where's your Master?

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Gone out, Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Why did not You go with Him?

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Because He went out in the Major's Cha∣riot, Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Where did They go to?

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: To the Major's, I suppose, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Suppose! Don't You know?

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: I believe so, but can't tell for certain, in∣deed, Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Believe! and suppose!—and don't know! and can't tell—You are all Fools—Go about your Business! [John going.]—Come here! [Returns.] Go to the Major's—No—it does not signify—go along—[John going.]—Yes, hark'ye! [Returns.] Go to the Major's, and see if your Master is there.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Give your Compliments? Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: My Compliments! Blockhead! Get along! [John going.] Come hither! [Returns.]—Can't You go to the Major's, and bring Me Word if Mr. Oakly is there, without taking any further Notice?

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Yes, Ma'am!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Well! Why don't You go then? And make Haste back—And d'ye hear? John! [John going, returns.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Nothing at all—go along—[John goes.]—How uneasy Mr. Oakly makes Me!—Hark'ye! John! [John returns.]

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Send the Porter here.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Yes, Madam! [Exit John.

SP.SPEAKER: Toil.
SP.P: So! She's in a rare Humour! I shall have a fine Time on't—[Aside.]—Will your Lady∣ship chuse to dress?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Prithee, Creature, don't teaze Me with your fiddle-faddle Stuff—I have a thousand Things to think of—Where is the Porter? Why has not that Booby sent Him? What is the Mean∣ing—

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Madam, my Master is this Moment re∣turned with Major Oakly, and my young Master, and the Lady that was here Yesterday.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Very well. [Exit John.]—Returned!—Yes, truly, he is returned—and in a very extraordinary Manner—This is setting Me at open Defiance—But I'll go down, and shew them I have too much Spirit to endure such Usage—[Going.]—Or stay—I'll not go amongst his Company—I'll go out—Toilet!

SP.SPEAKER: Toil.
SP.P: Ma'am!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Order the Coach. I'll go out. [Toilet going.]—Toilet! stay!—I'll e'en go down to them—No—Toilet!

SP.SPEAKER: Toil.
SP.P: Ma'am!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Order Me a boil'd Chicken—I'll not go down to Dinner—I'll dine in my own Room, and sup there—I'll not see his Face these three Days. [Exeunt.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Oakly, Major Oakly, Charles, and Harriot.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: My dear Harriot, do not make Yourself so uneasy.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Alas! I have too much Cause for my Un∣easiness. Who knows what that vile Lord has done with my Father?

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: Be comforted, Madam! We shall soon hear of Mr. Russet, and all will be well, I dare say.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: You are too good to Me, Sir!—But I can assure You, I am not a little concern'd on your Account as well as my own; and if I did not flat∣ter Myself with the Hopes of explaining every Thing to Mrs. Oakly's Satisfaction, I should never forgive Myself for having disturbed the Peace of such a worthy Family.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Don't mind that, Madam! They'll be very good Friends again—This is nothing among married People▪—'Sdeath! Here She is!—No—Its only Mrs. Toilet.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: Well, Toilet, What now? [Toil. whispers.] Not well?—Can't come down to Dinner?—Wants to see Me above?—Hark'ye, Brother, what shall I do?

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: If You go, you're undone.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Go, Sir!—Go to Mrs. Oakly—Indeed, You had better—

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: 'Sdeath, Brother! don't budge a Foot—This is all Fractiousness and Ill-humour—

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: No—I'll not go—Tell Her I have Com∣pany, and We shall be glad to see Her here.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: That's right.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: Suppose I go, and watch how She pro∣ceeds?

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: What d'ye mean?—You wou'd not go to Her!—Are You mad?

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: By no Means go to Her—I only want to know how She takes it.—I'll lie perdue in my Study, and observe Her Motions.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: I don't like this pitiful ambuscade Work—This Bush-fighting—Why can't You stay here?—Ay! ay!—I know how it will be—She'll come bounce in upon You with a Torrent of An∣ger and Passion, or, if necessary, a whole Flood of Tears, and carry all before Her at once.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: You shall find that you're mistaken, Ma∣jor!—Don't imagine, because I wish not to be void of Humanity, that I am destitute of Resolu∣tion. Now I am convinc'd I'm in the Right, I'll support that Right with ten Times your Steadi∣ness.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: You talk this well, Brother!

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: I'll do it well, Brother!

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: If You don't, you're undone.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: Never fear! never fear! [Exit▪

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Well, Charles!

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: I can't bear to see my Harriot so uneasy. I'll go immediately in quest of Mr. Russet. Per∣haps I may learn at the Inn where his Lordship's Ruffians have carried Him.

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: [without.] Here? Yes, yes, I know She's here well enough. Come along, Sir Harry, come along.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P:
He's here!—My Father! I know his Voice. Where is Mr. Oakly? O, now, good Sir,
[To Major.] Do but pacify Him, and you'll be a Friend indeed.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Russet, Lord Trinket, and Sir Harry Beagle.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Trink.
SP.P: There! Sir—I told you it was so.

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: Ay, ay, it is too plain.—O you provok∣ing Slut!—Elopement after Elopement! And at last to have your Father carried off by Violence! To endanger my Life! Zouns! I am so angry, I dare not trust Myself within reach of You.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: I can assure You, Sir, that your Daughter is entirely—

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: You assure Me? You are the Fellow that has perverted her Mind—That has set my own Child against Me—

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: If You will but hear Me, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: I won't hear a Word You say—I'll have my Daughter—I won't hear a Word.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Nay, Mr. Russet, hear Reason. If You will but have Patience—

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: I'll have no Patience—I'll have my Daugh∣ter, and She shall marry Sir Harry To-night.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Trink.
SP.P: That is dealing rather too much en ca∣valier with Me, Mr. Russet, 'pon Honour. You take no Notice of my Pretensions, though my Rank and Family—

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: What care I for Rank and Family? I don't want to make my Daughter a rantipole Woman of Quality. I'll give Her to whom, I please. Take Her away, Sir Harry! She shall marry You To∣night.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: For Heaven's sake, Sir, hear Me but a Moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: Hold your Tongue, Girl! Take Her away, Sir Harry, take Her away.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: It must not be.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Only three Words, Mr. Russet.—

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: Why don't the Booby take Her?—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir. Har.
SP.P: Hold hard! hold hard! You are all on a wrong Scent: Hold hard! I say, hold hard!—Hark ye, Squire Russet!

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: Well! what now?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Har.
SP.P: It was proposed, You know, to match Me with Miss Harriot—But She can't take kindly to me.—When one has made a bad Bet, it is best to hedge off, You know—and so I have e'en swopped Her with Lord Trinket here for his brown Horse Nabob, that He bought of Lord Whistle∣jacket, for Fifteen hundred Guineas.

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: Swopped Her? Swopped my Daughter for a Horse? Zouns, Sir, what d'ye mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Har.
SP.P: Mean? Why I mean to be off, to be sure—It won't do—I tell You, it won't do—First of all I knocked up Myself and my Horses, when they took for London—and now I have been stewed aboard a Tender—I have wasted three Stone at least—If I cou'd have rid my Match, it would not have grieved me—And so as I said before, I have swopped Her for Nabob.

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: The Devil take Nabob, and Yourself, and Lord Trinket, and—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Trink.
SP.P: Pardon! je vous demande pardon Monsieur Russet! 'pon Honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: Death and the Devil! I shall go distracted. My Daughter plotting against Me—the—

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Come, come, Mr. Russet, I am your Man after all, give Me but a Moment's Hearing, and I'll engage to make Peace between You and your Daughter, and throw the Blame where it ought to fall most deservedly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Har.
SP.P: Ay, ay, that's right. Put the Saddle on the right Horse, my Buck!

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: Well, Sir!—What d'ye say?—Speak—I don't know what to do—

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: I'll speak the Truth, let who will be offended by it.—I have Proof presumptive and positive for You, Mr. Russet. From his Lord∣ship's Behaviour at Lady Freelove's, when my Ne∣phew rescued Her, We may fairly conclude that He wou'd stick at no Measures to carry his Point.—There's Proof presumptive.—But Sir We can give You Proof positive too—Proof under his Lordship's own Hand, that He, likewise, was the Contriver of the gross Affront that has just been offered You.

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: Hey! How!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Trink.
SP.P: Every Syllable Romance, 'pon Honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Gospel, every Word on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: This Letter will convince You, Sir!—In Consequence of what happened at Lady Freelove's, his Lordship thought fit to send Me a Challenge: But the Messenger blundered, and gave Me this Letter instead of it. [Giving the Letter.] I have the Case which inclosed it in my Pocket.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Trink.
SP.P: Forgery from Beginning to End, 'pon Honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Truth upon my Honour.—But read, read, Mr. Russet, read and be convinced.

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: Let Me see—let Me see—[Reading.]—Um—um—um—um—so! so!—um—um—um—Damnation!—Wish Me Success—obedient Slave—Trinket.—Fire and Fury! How dare You do this?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Trink.
SP.P: When You are cool, Mr. Russet, I will explain this Matter to You.

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: Cool? 'Sdeath and Hell!—I'll never be cool again—I'll be revenged.—So my Harriot, my dear Girl is innocent at last—Say so, Harriot, tell Me You are innocent. [Embracing Her.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: I am, indeed, Sir! and happy beyond Ex∣pression, at your being convinced of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: I am glad on't—I am glad on't—I be∣lieve You▪ Harriot!—You was always a good Girl.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: So She is, an excellent Girl!—Worth a Regiment of such Lords and Baronets—Come, Sir, finish every Thing handsomely at once—Come,—Charles will have a handsome Fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: Marry!—She durst not do it.—

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Consider, Sir, They have long been fond of each other,—old Acquaintance—faithful Lovers—Turtles—and may be very happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: Well, well—since Things are so—I love my Girl—Hark'ye, young Oakly, if You don't make Her a good▪Husband, You'll break my Heart, you Rogue.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: Do not doubt it, Sir! my Harriot has reformed Me altogether.

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: Has She?—Why then—there—Heaven bless you both—there—now there's an End on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Har.
SP.P: So, my Lord, You and I are both distanced—A hollow Thing, dammee.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Trink.
SP.P: N'importe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Har.
SP.P: [Aside.] Now this Stake is drawn, my Lord may be for hedging off mayhap. Ecod! I'll go to Jack Speed's, and secure Nabob, and be out of Town in an Hour—Soho! Lady Freelove! Yoics! [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: My dear Miss Russet, You'll excuse—

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: Mrs. Oakly, at your Ladyship's Service.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: Married?

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Not yet, Madam, but my Father has been so good as to give his Consent.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: I protest, I am prodigiously glad of it. My Dear, I give You Joy—and You, Mr. Oakly—I wish You Joy, Mr. Russet, and all the good Company—for I think They are most of Them Parties concerned.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: How easy, impudent, and familiar!—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: Lord Trinket here too! I vow I did not see your Lordship before.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Trink.
SP.P: Your Ladyship's most obedient Slave. [Bowing.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: You seem grave, my Lord!—Come, come, I know there has been some Difference be∣tween You and Mr. Oakly—You must give Me Leave to be a Mediator in this Affair.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Trink.
SP.P: Here has been a small Fracas to be sure, Madam!—We are all blown, 'pon Honour.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: Blown! What do You mean, my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Trink.
SP.P: Nay, your Ladyship knows that I never mind these Things, and I know that they never discompose your Ladyship—But Things have happened a little en travers—The little Billet that I sent your Ladyship, has fallen into the Hands of that Gentleman—[Pointing to Char.]—and so—there has been a little Brouillerie about it—that's all.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: You talk to Me, my Lord, in a very extraordinary Stile—If You have been guilty of any Misbehaviour, I am sorry for it; but your ill Conduct can fasten no Imputation on Me.—Miss Russet will justify Me sufficiently.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Had not your Ladyship better appeal to my Friend Charles here?—The Letter! Charles!—Out with it this Instant!

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: Yes, I have the Credentials of her Lady∣ship's Integrity in my Pocket.—Mr. Russet, the Letter You read a little while ago, was inclosed in this Cover, which also I now think it my Duty to put into your Hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: [Reading.] To the Right Honourable Lady Freelove—'Sdeath and Hell!—and now I recollect, the Letter itself was pieced with Scraps of French, and Madam, and Your Ladyship—Fire and Fury! Madam, how came You to use Me so? I am obliged to You then for the Insult that has been offered Me.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: What is all this? Your Obligations to Me, Mr. Russet, are of a Nature that—

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: Fine Obligations! I dare say I am partly oblig'd to You too for the Attempt on my Daugh∣ter by that Thing of a Lord yonder at your House. Zouns! Madam, these are Injuries never to be for∣given—They are the grossest Affronts to Me and my Family—All the World shall know Them—Zouns!—I'll—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Free.
SP.P: Mercy on Me! how boisterous are these Country Gentlemen! Why really, Mr. Russet, You rave like a Man in Bedlam—I am afraid you'll beat Me—and then You swear most abominably.—How can You be so vulgar?—I see the Meaning of this low Malice—But the Re∣putations of Women of Quality are not so easily impeached—My Rank places Me above the Scan∣dal of little People, and I shall meet such petty Insolence with the greatest Ease and Tranquillity.—But You and your simple Girl will be the Sufferers—I had some Thoughts of introducing Her into the first Company—But now, Madam, I shall neither receive nor return your Visits, and will entirely withdraw my Protection from the ordinary Part of the Family. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: Zouns! what Impudence! that's worse than all the rest.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Trink.
SP.P: Fine presence of Mind, faith!—The true French Nonchalence—But good Folks, why such a deal of Rout and Tapage about nothing at all?—If Mademoiselle Harriot had rather be Mrs. Oakly than Lady Trinket—Why—I wish her Joy, that's all—Mr. Russet, I wish You Joy of your Son-in-Law—Mr. Oakly, I wish You Joy of the Lady—and You, Madam, [To Harriot.] of the Gentleman—And in short, I wish You all Joy of one another, 'pon Honour! [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: There's a fine Fellow of a Lord now! The Devil's in your London Folks of the first Fashion, as You call Them. They will rob You of your Estate, debauch your Daughter, or lie with your Wife—and all as if They were doing You a Favour—'Pon Honour!—[Bell rings violently▪

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Hey! What now?

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: D'ye hear Major, d'ye hear?

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Zouns! What a Clatter!—She'll pull down all the Bells in the House.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: My Observations since I left You, have con∣firm'd my Resolution. I see plainly, that her Good-humour, and her Ill-humour, her Smiles, her Tears, and her Fits, are all calculated to play upon Me▪

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Did not I always tell You so? Its the way with them all—They will be rough, and smooth, and hot, and cold, and all in a Breath. Any Thing to get the better of us.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P:
She is in all Moods at present, I promise You—I am at once angry and ashamed of Her; and yet she is so ridiculous I can't help laughing at Her—There has She been in her Chamber,
fuming and fretting, and dispatching a Messenger to Me every two Minutes—Servant after Servant—Now she insists on my coming to Her—Now again She writes a Note to intreat—Then Toilet is sent to let Me know that She is ill—absolutely dying—Then, the very next Minute, she'll never see my Face again—She'll go out of the House directly. [Bell rings.] Again!—now the Storm rises!—

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: It will soon drive this Way then—now Brother, prove Yourself a Man—You have gone too far to retreat.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: Retreat!—Retreat!—No, no!—I'll pre∣serve the Advantage I have gain'd, I am deter∣min'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Ay, ay!—keep your Ground!—fear no∣thing!—Up with your noble Heart! Good Disci∣pline makes good Soldiers; stick close to my Ad∣vice, and You may stand buff to a Tigress—

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: Here she is, by Heavens—Now! Brother!

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: And now! Brother!—Now, or never!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: I think, Mr. Oakly, You might have had Humanity enough to have come to see how I did. You have taken your Leave, I sup∣pose, of all Tenderness and Affection—But I'll be calm—I'll not throw myself into a Pas∣sion—You want to drive me out of your House—I see what You aim at, and will be aforehand with You—Let Me keep my Temper!—I'll send for a Chair, and leave the House this In∣stant.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: True, my Love! I knew You wou'd not think of dining in your own Chamber alone, when I had Company below. You shall sit at the Head of the Table, as You ought to be sure, as You say, and make my Friends welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Excellent Raillery! Look ye, Mr. Oakly, I see the Meaning of all this affected Cool∣ness and Indifference.—

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: My Dear, consider where You are—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: You wou'd be glad, I find, to get Me out of your House, and have all your Flirts about You.—

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: Before all this Company! Fie.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: But I'll disappoint You, for I shall remain in it to support my due Authority—As for You, Major Oakly!—

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Hey day! What have I done?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: I think You might find better Em∣ployment, than to create Divisions between mar∣ried People—and You, Sir!—

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: Nay, but my Dear!—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Might have more Sense, as well as Tenderness, than to give Ear to such idle Stuff.—

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: Lord! Lord!—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: You and your wise Counsellor there, I suppose, think to carry all your Points with Me.—

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: Was ever any Thing—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: But it won't do Sir! You shall find that I will have my own Way, and that I will go∣vern my own Family.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: You had better learn to govern Yourself by half. Your Passion makes You ridiculous.
