Did ever any body see so much Fury and Violence, af∣fronting your best Friends, breaking my Peace, and disconcerting your own Temper? And all for what? for nothing. 'Sdeath! Madam, at these Years You ought to know better.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: At these Years!—Very fine!—Am I to be talk'd to in this Manner?

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P:
Talk'd to!—Why not?—You have talk'd to Me long enough—almost talked Me to Death—and I have taken it all in hopes of making
You quiet—But all in vain, for the more one bears, the worse You are. Patience, I find, is all thrown away upon You—and henceforward, come what may, I am resolved to be Master of my own House.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: So! so!—Master indeed!—Yes, Sir, and you'll take care to have Mistresses enough too, I warrant You.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: Perhaps I may; but they shall be quiet ones, I can assure You.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Indeed! and do You think that I am such a tame Fool as to sit quietly and bear all this?—You shall know, Sir, that I will resent this Be∣haviour—You shall find that I have a Spirit—

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: Of the Devil.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Intolerable!—You shall find then that I will exert that Spirit. I am sure I have need of it.—As soon as my House is once cleared again, I'll shut my Doors against all Company—You shan't see a single Soul for this Month.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: 'Sdeath! Madam, but I will.—I'll keep open House for a Year—I'll send Cards to the whole Town—Mr. Oakly's Route! All the World will come—And I'll go among the World too—I'll be mewed up no longer.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Provoking Insolence!—This is not to be endured. Look'ye, Mr. Oakly—

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: And look'ye Mrs. Oakly, I will have my own Way.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Nay then, let Me tell You, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: And let Me tell You, Madam, I will not be crossed—I won't be made a Fool.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Why, You won't let Me speak—

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: Because You don't speak as You ought—Madam! Madam! You shan't look, nor walk, nor talk, nor think, but as I please.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Was there ever such a Monster! I can bear this no longer. [Bursts into Tears.] O you vile Man!—I see through your Design—You cruel, barbarous, inhuman—Such Usage to your poor Wife!—You'll be the Death of Her.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: She shan't be the Death of Me, I am de∣termined.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: That it shou'd ever come to this!—To be contradicted—[Sobbing.]—insulted—abused—hated—'Tis too much—my Heart will burst with—oh—oh—[Falls into a Fit.

DIV2.STAGE: Harriot, Charles, &c. run to her Assistance.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: [Interposing.] Let Her alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Sir, Mrs. Oakly—

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: For Heaven's Sake, Sir, She will be—

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: Let Her alone, I say. I won't have Her touched—Let Her alone—If her Passions throw Her into Fits, let the Strength of them carry Her through them.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Pray, my dear Sir, let Us assist Her! She may—

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: I don't care—You shan't touch Her—Let Her bear them patiently—She'll learn to behave better another Time.—Let Her alone, I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs, Oak.
SP.P: [Rising.] O you Monster!—You Villain!—You base Man!—Wou'd You let Me die for want of Help?—Wou'd You—

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: Bless Me! Madam, your Fit is very vio∣lent—Take Care of Yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Despised—ridiculed—But I'll be revenged—You shall see, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: Tol-de-rol loll-de-roll loll-de-rol loll. [singing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: What, am I made a Jest of? Ex∣posed to all the World—If there's Law or Justice—

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: Tol-de-rol loll-de-roll loll-de-rol loll. [singing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: I shall burst with Anger—Have a care, Sir, You may repent this—Scorned and made ridiculous!—No Power on Earth shall hinder my Revenge. [Going.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: [Interposing.] Stay, Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Let Me go. I cannot bear this Place.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Let Me beseech You, Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: What does the Girl mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Courage! Brother. You have done Wonders. Apart.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: I think, She'll have no more Fits.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Stay, Madam!—Pray stay!—but one Moment.—I have been a painful Witness of your Uneasiness, and in great Part the innocent Occasion of it. Give Me Leave then—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: I did not expect indeed to have found You here again. But however.—

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: I see the Agitation of your Mind, and it makes Me miserable. Suffer Me to tell You the real Truth. I can explain every Thing to your Satisfaction.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: May be so—I cannot argue with You.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: Pray, Madam, hear Her—for my Sake—for your own—Dear Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: Well—well—proceed.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: I shall relapse, I can't bear to see Her so uneasy. Apart.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Hush!—Hush!

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: I understand, Madam, that your first Alarm was occasioned by a Letter from my Father to your Nephew.

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: I was in a bloody Passion to be sure, Madam!—The Letter was not over-civil I be∣lieve—I did not know but the young Rogue had ruined my Girl.—But it's all over now, and so—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: You was here Yesterday, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: Yes, I came after Harriot. I thought I shou'd find my young Madam with my young Sir, here.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: With Charles, did You say? Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: Ay, with Charles, Madam! The young Rogue has been fond of Her a long Time, and She of Him, it seems.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: I fear I have been to blame. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.P: I ask Pardon, Madam, for the Disturbance I made in your House.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: And the abrupt Manner, in which I came into it, demands a thousand Apologies. But the Occasion must be my Excuse.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: How have I been mistaken! [Aside.]—But did not I overhear You and Mr. Oakly—[To Harriot.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Dear Madam! You had but a partial Hearing of our Conversation. It related entirely to this Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: To put it beyond Doubt, Madam, Mr. Russet and my Guardian have consented to our Marriage; and We are in Hopes that You will not withhold your Approbation.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P:
I have no further Doubt—I see You are innocent, and it was cruel to suspect You—
You have taken a load of Anguish off my Mind—And yet your kind Interposition comes too late. Mr. Oakly's Love for Me is entirely destroyed.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: I must go to Her—Apart.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Not yet!—Not yet! Apart.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Do not disturb Yourself with such Appre∣hensions. I am sure Mr. Oakly loves You most af∣fectionately.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: I can hold no longer. [Going to Her.] My Affection for You, Madam, is as warm as ever, Nothing can ever extinguish it. My constrained Be∣haviour cut me to the Soul—For within these few Hours it has been all constrained—and it was with the utmost Difficulty that I was able to support it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: O, Mr. Oakly, how have I exposed Myself! What low Arts has my Jealousy induced Me to practice! I see my Folly, and fear that You can never forgive Me.

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: Forgive You!—You are too good, my Love!—Forgive You!—Can You forgive Me?—This Change transports Me.—Brother! Mr. Russet! Charles! Harriot! give Me Joy!—I am the happiest Man in the World.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Joy, much Joy to you both! though, by-the-bye, You are not a little obliged to Me for it. Did not I tell You I wou'd cure all the Disorders in your Family? I beg Pardon, Sister, for taking the Liberty to prescribe for You. My Medicines have been somewhat rough, I believe, but they have had an admirable Effect, and so don't be an∣gry with your Physician.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: I am indeed obliged to You, and I feel—

SP.SPEAKER: Oak.
SP.P: Nay, my Dear, no more of this. All that's past must be utterly forgotten.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Oak.
SP.P: I have not merited this Kindness, but it shall hereafter be my Study to deserve it. Away with all idle Jealousies! and since my Suspicions have hitherto been groundless, I am resolved for the Future never to suspect at all.

LG.L: LAdies! I've had a Squabble with the Poet—
About his Characters—and You shall know it.
Young Man, said I, restrain your saucy Satire!
My Part's ridiculous—false—out of Nature.
Fine Draughts indeed of Ladies! sure You hate 'em!
Why, Sir!—My Part is Scandalum Magnatûm.
Lord, Ma'am, said He, to copy Life my Trade is,
And Poets ever have made free with Ladies:
One Simon—the Duce take such Names as these!—
A hard Greek Name—O—ay—Simonides—
He shew'd,—our Freaks, this Whim and that Desire,
Rose first from Earth, Sea, Air, nay, some from Fire;
Or that we owe our Persons, Minds, and Features
To Birds, forsooth, and filthy four legg'd Creatures.
The Dame, of Manners various, Temper fickle,
Now all for Pleasure, now the Conventicle!
Who Prays, then Raves, now Calm, now all Commotion,
Rises, another Venus, from the Ocean.
Constant at ev'ry Sale, the Curious Fair,
Who longs for Dresden, and old China Ware;
Who doats on Pagods, and gives up vile Man
For niddle-noddle Figures from Japan;
Critick in Jars and Josses, shews her Birth
Drawn, like the brittle Ware itself, from Earth.
The flaunting She, so stately, rich, and vain,
Who gains her Conquests by her Length of Train;
While all her Vanity is under Sail,
Sweeps, a proud Peacock, with a gaudy Tail.
Husband and Wife, with Sweets! and Dears! and Loves!
What are They, but a Pair of cooing Doves?
But seiz'd with Spleen, Fits, Humonrs, and all that,
Your Dove and Turtle turn to Dog and Cat.
The Gossip, Prude, Old Maid, Coquette, and Trapes,
Are Parrots, Foxes, Magpies, Wasps, and Apes:
But She, with ev'ry Charm of Form and Mind,
Oh! She's—sweet Soul!—the Phoenix of her Kind.
The Phoenix of her Kind!—upon my Word
He's a sly Wretch—pray?—is there such a Bird?
This his Apology!—'Tis rank Abuse—
A fresh Affront, instead of an Excuse!
His own Sex rather such Description suits:
Why dont He draw their Characters—The Brutes!
Ay, let Him paint those ugly Monsters, Men!—
Mean time—Mend We our Lives—He'll mend his Pen.
